text:
Made this exactly as directed and found it to be not at all too sweet.  I have switched from using the elbow macaroni to a whole 16 oz box of rotini and the amount of sauce is still enough.  I have found that making the sauce the day before and then adding it to the chilled macaroni just before serving makes a creamier salad and it isn't absorbed by the pasta.  Love it love it love it!

text:
I am rating this recipe 5 stars because the basis for the dressing is SO good!!  I did make some changes, but I think it is just a very versatile recipe.  I used miracle whip instead of mayo, apple cider vinegar instead of white and half the sugar called for.  I used white onion (I didn't have any red ones, although I would have preferred that!!) and some cold left over frozen sweet peas as the ones in the can would be too mushy.  I used cucumber, and chopped boiled egg.  I made this at the last minute, as we decided to grill burgers on our grill, even though we are thigh deep in snow! Hahah!!  It was great even after 45 minutes in the fridge, but it was creamy.  We ate leftovers for lunch today and loved it even more!  Will definitely make again.  I have a family of 5 and by cutting the recipe in half, we didn't have too much leftover!

text:
Great macaroni salad and definitely classic picnic food!  Everyone has their own take on these types of things and I adjusted this to my own taste preferences as well.  I used lite mayo and cut the sugar down to 1/4 cup.  I used 2 Tbsp. of mustard, one yellow and one dijon and next time I might cut back on that just a bit.  I added 1/2 tsp. of garlic powder and 4 hard boiled eggs.  I left out the green pepper and used a bunch of chopped green onions.  I did add the carrots and a 5 oz. jar of drained and chopped green olives with pimento peppers.  This reminds me a lot of what my Grandma used to make every summer.

i think the dressing is fantastic.  it's a little sweet, a little zingy from the vinegar, a little mustardy, it all blends well.  i truly love it... just not on macaroni.  i think the dressing would be a star on potatoes... to make potato salad.  also, next time i'll just add a splash of vinegar because it made my dressing runny rather than creamy.  --- UPDATE --- i tried the dressing again with potatoes and it was heavenly!  all i did was decrease the sugar portion to about half a cup... yum yum.  (just a note - after a day, the sweetness cuts down.)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Classic is the key word here ... nothing to pretty it up, nothing to add additional flavors, nothing to create a "change" ... just a perfect, classic recipe everyone will love!  I not only think its perfect as is, but is also the best base for getting crazy with your own preferences.  Here are a few suggestions/hints I have found to be helpful ... some reviews have mentioned it too runny, too sweet, too much onion, or needing some chopped egg, I personally found the "runny" dressing to substancially thicken up overnight in the fridge, but if you are serving within an hour or two of making, I'd suggest tossing with partial dressing and saving the rest to add if necessary just prior to serving that way you control the wetness.  I actually prefer adding a bit of dressing to give it a little fresh kick just before the serve.  As for the sugar, I have found a little less is needed if you use white vinegar and mayo, but all is needed if using apple cider and miracle whip. It also aids in the consistency of the dressing.  To somewhat counter the bite of the onion I chop it a bit fine to blend in better as I'm not a fan of chunky onion bites, but certainly using less is an easy fix. As for the chopped egg, its one of those preference things but often a "must" for some so throw it in there. Same with adding cheese, or mini shrimp, or other veggies, there is no limit to personalizing this perfect start.  But, for a fresh, classic macaroni salad, you won't go wrong with "as is" either!

text:
5 star though a tad on the sweet side for me, but perfect for my hubby's taste buds.  Reminiscent of a cole slaw dressing and immediately after mixing the dressing all you can taste is sweet, but this dressing blends beautifully after chilling for 4+ hours and settles right down.  Many reviewers noted that the dressing was runny; to counteract that, I added 1/2 the sauce after draining the macaroni and let sit for an hour.  This allowed the macaroni to absorb the dressing and gave it an added flavor boost.  Much like other reviewers, I added and subtracted to suit the family's preferences, ie., eggs, green onions, etc., but the dressing is really what makes this salad outstanding.  Served this with a pork tenderloin recipe from FoodNetwork.  The spicy sauce on the tenderloin was a perfect counter for the sweetness of the salad.  Outstanding and definitely worthy of 5 stars which are not to be given lightly!

text:
I was in charge of making macaroni salad for 125 teenage girls at a retreat. I used this recipe (times 12!). The salad was a huge hit. That's really saying something considering how picky teen girls can be. 

I've been trying to find a good macaroni salad recipe for years ever since I tried some at a great Hawaiian restaurant. Nothing has really satisfied me til now. This recipe is a keeper.

The only thing I did differently was to not rinse the noodles but add the vinegar right after draining. That's what Cooks Illustrated recommends when making mac salad.

text:
This recipe delivers a delicious, classic macaroni salad that most people will love. The first time I made it, I followed the recipe exactly and it was a big hit at a bbq we had. Subsequent times, I tweaked things around so it would fit our tastes more closely, and now it's a commonly requested item at potlucks, bbqs, and family dinners.  The changes I've made are as follows: a) I cut the mustard (ha) in half  b) I decrease the sugar to 1/3 cup c) I leave out the listed veggies and instead add eggs, sweet pickles, 4T pimentos, and green onions d) I double the dressing recipe and put half on to make the salad then add the other half after 4 hours.   This is also a great salad to toss in crab - it adds quite a great flavor!

text:
This is an excellent macaroni salad!  Having only ever had macaroni salad with plain mayo as dressing...I was a little scared when I started putting the dressing ingredients together. I tasted a small helping immediately after mixing in the veggies and pasta, and it tasted really sweet....HOWEVER...I just had another helping after it has been refrigerated for about 3 hours and it is just yummy!! All the flavors really came together and it's not too sweet or too tangy. Also, the dressing/pasta ratio is perfect, just the right amount of moistness.   As for presentation....I love the yellow color that is had from the mustard...and I'm glad I decided to add the shredded carrots. The orange and green colors from the veggies make this a very pretty dish. I left out the pimentos, simply because I forgot to buy them.  This yummy, refreshing salad will definately be showing up this summer during cookouts and picnics.  I think next time I make this, I might try adding hard boiled eggs, cubed cheese or diced ham.

text:
This is a great recipe AS-IS. 

I will mention that the amount of sugar seems like a lot, but if you allow it to sit overnight (or longer) it tastes so better. The next time I made it I did cut the sugar to 1/4 t and it was really good immediately, but after sitting overnight it was very bland. I keep this in mind if I'm making it for right away, or for an event in the next couple of days.

I've made this for several food days and family events. It's almost always the first one gone and I get many rave reviews :)

text:
I love this recipe and have made a variation of it for years.  Instead of mixing up the mayo, vinegar, and sugar though, I mix the about 1/3 mayo with 2/3 salad dressing and cut back slightly on the mustard.  I too add an egg and because I think celery is what tends to make the leftover salad watery (well, if you have leftver), I leave it out and use celery seed instead.  I also like to use red pepper instead of green and add a cup of cubed sharp cheddar cheese.  This is a very versatile salad and always go over big with family and friends.

text:
I loved this recipe.  I read many other reviews and also many a few changes.  Because there are only 2 of us I downsized the recipe.  I used green onions finely chopped, and yellow, orange and red peppers finley diced. I used less than 1/4 cup sugar. I used 1 tbsp white & 1 tbsp cider vinegar.  I used 1 tbsp Dijon & 1/2 tbsp dry mustard. I also used Mircale Whip and added 2 tbsp sour cream.  For more color I added 1/3 cup frozen peas and corn and sprinkled smokey paprika.  I also added 4 strips and cooked bacon coarsely chopped.  It was the first time in many years I have made this type of salad and I will make it again.  Thanks to you all for your reviews...

text:
I tripled the recipe for a picnic. I didn't add the carrots or pimento peppers. I used a combination of white vinegar and apple cider vinegar because I didn't have enough of the white. Worked great. Also, I ran out of regular mustard so I used dijon and again, worked great. Due to the reviews, I decided to play it safe and reduce the amount of sugar by half. Seemed perfect. I made it the night before and the flavors were great the next day. I didn't reserve any of the dressing for the next day but I do see where it would be nice for people who like creamier salad to add some at the last minute. However, I thought it was great regardless. I chopped all the veggies really small because I don't like having huge chunks of any particular thing stand out. The flavor distributes better in my opinion, when everything is chopped small.

None
text:
The recipe is a real good one... Until it came down to the sugar. Macaroni salad should NOT have that amount of sugar!! I only made half the recipe- every other ingredient as called for. From there I added 1/2 Tbs. sugar as needed to aquire desired taste. DO NOT add the full amount of sugar called for unless you want a sickeningly SWEET mac salad! I think its nearly a better alternative to skip sugar all together & use some sweet relish. Otherwise, a good, decent mac salad... I also diced up some cheddar cheese & threw it in for a personal preference- turned out wonderful & I wish I had made the full amount after seeing how fast it was devoured!! Will absolutely make again- just no sugar. Substituting with sweet relish is a better, more appetizing option. Or just leave out the sugar- it really does not need it (especially if you are using Miracle Whip which is on the sweeter side).
UPDATE: after making this several more times, everyone has agreed the sugar called for is outrageous. We start with 1Tbsp. and add more as needed. Also, adding in 3-4 hard boiled eggs is a very nice twist! And we substituted peas for the celery while leaving out green bell pepper. This is a dish that always disappears, and very popular. Just needs some minor changes.

text:
Excellent recipe. I have never cared for macaroni salad, absolutely can't stand store bought, so I made this for my husband. Served it at a party and everyone loved it. Even me. I read several reviews and used the following suggestions; double the ingredients for the dressing escept cut the sugar in half. MAKE THE NIGHT BEFORE! It will be runny but letting it sit overnight the noodles will absorbe the dressing, blending all the flavours and leaving it with just the right consistancy. I have made it with and without the carots either way is great. I don't like pimento so I leave that out and add sliced black olives.

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:

userID:
1544303
Display Name:
SusyQ
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
13
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/48933.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made this recipe, I did not read any other reviews. I made this exactly as written, and had the "bad feeling" about the 2/3 cup of sugar (and I used raw sugar, as I don't eat anything refined/over processed). It was TOO sweet. 

The next time I made this, I changed it quite a bit: First, I omitted the sugar altogether.  I used Apple Cider Vinegar instead, and used German mustard. I add more celery and carrots, and half of a jalapeno (very finely chopped). I don't add pimentos, but I do add some cubed sharp cheddar cheese. I try to cube it small enough so that every forkful has a bit of cheese. Sometimes I add paprika, depending on whether or not I remember.

My boyfriend will gladly eat the entire dish in one sitting, but if I ration him, it'll last him and I about two days (using it as a side, and sometimes as the main entree). I hope I've helped!

text:
This is my go-to recipe for macaroni salad since the first time I made it. Everything a classic should have, nothing it shouldn't. The only reason I gave it four stars instead of five is because it calls for way more sugar than I think is necessary. I cut it in half and it's plenty sweet enough. I could probably cut back a bit more and still be satisfied. If making it for the first time, I would recommend starting out with half (or less) the amount of sugar than the recipe states and see what you think. You can always add more, if that's your preference.

I love macaroni salad, and since I have found this recipe, it's the only one I make. I have yet to try a macaroni salad that I like better than this one. This is one of my very favorite recipes on this site, I make it all the time and I am often asked to bring this to get-togethers.

This is a very yummy macaroni salad. I halved the recipe though because I was the only one eating it. I read alot of reviews and it seemed like alot said it was too sweet so I added the sugar slowly until I found it just right, I ended up using only half of what was called for. I didn't use celery or peppers as I had none and used 2 eggs. I was making it to eat for lunch so I used only half the dressing at first but reserved the rest for tomorrow if it needs more. I do agree with another review that this would be even better with potato salad and will try it. I will definately be making this dressing over and over again, thanks for sharing. UPDATE: I just made this with potatoes and it turned out even better then with the macaroni. I still added the 2 eggs as it adds more flavor to it. I made the macaroni salad once with no eggs and it was kind of bland like it was missing something, so adding the eggs adds alot of flavor.

text:
As written, I thought this recipe had far too much sugar -- I cut it down by more than half.  Otherwise, I thought it was delicious.  Instead of prepared mustard (which I don't much care for) I used Dijon mustard, and it was really nice.  It wasn't 'yellow', and I think it gives a nicer flavour.  Because I'm not too fond of raw onion generally, I think that next time I'll try it with pickled onions.  I liked that the dressing wasn't too heavy, unlike most pasta salad dressings I've tried.  Thanks!  (Oh yeah, my boyfriend loved it!  And he's the "pasta salad" connoisseur... lol)___ Update:  I omitted the onions altogether this time, but used 1 each of a red and green pepper, the celery and grated carrot, and I added beets.  Delicious!!  And soooo pretty!  (Note: I didn't use pickled beets -- I buy fresh beets and then roast them in foil in the oven for about an hour at 350.  When they cool, I peel them and slice them.)

text:
Delicious! I omit the mustard, (not a classic macaroni salad ingredient) and used only a tablespoon of sugar. I use dill pickle juice instead of plain vinegar, and some chopped up pickles too. Didn't use bell pepper or pimento (didn't have any). Wonderful, addictive! Hint: best the day after. Just add a few tablespoons of milk or dill pickle juice to moisten it up before serving again, since the pasta soaks up a lot of the dressing.

I cut the sugar in half and this was still far too sweet.  Maybe this recipe is "classic" in other areas, but it's definitely not the norm for my area of Virginia. text:
When I first started making this I wasn't too sure...it looked to "wet' and seemed to have a lot of onion.  This turned out to be FANTASTIC!  I didn't have celery or carrot, so I added a large chopped onion, a small jar of drained and chopped pimentos, and about 6 small dill pickles, chopped.  I also didn't have white vinegar so I used apple cider vinegar instead.  I read a lot of reviews about this being too sweet, but I still added a scant 1/2  cup and it was perfect.  With all those onions and vinegar, you need some sweetness to tone them down.  I also thought the salt and pepper quantities were perfect as well.  One of my favorite recipes I've gotten from this site in a long time!

text:
This tasted like how a true macaroni salad should taste.  I should add though, I found the "dressing" mixture to be a little on the thin side.  I'm used to a thicker coating on my macaroni salad.  I'm guessing this is because of the lower fat mayo I used, but it could be that plus the combo of vinegar that thinned things out.  I'll probably never buy full fat mayo, so there's no way for me to confirm this.  But just thought I'd mention it in case others are also intending on using low fat mayo.  Other than that, this was spot on in taste and appearance.  Thanks for sharing!  And with any cold starchy salad (macaroni, potato, etc), leaving it in the fridge to firm up is a must.  It makes all the difference and it also gives the flavours a chance to come through

text:
Have tried this 2 ways ..as written and with my modifications .. As written for me its a 3.5 stars...with a few modification for personal taste it 4.5 .. hence the 4 star rating. It is flavorful and definately needs to refridgerate over night for best flavor. The recipe calls for Mayo .. dont use Miracle Whip.
My Modifications .. cut the pasta to 2 cups , eggs to 2 , and added 1/2 cup of plain greek yogurt for a creamier texture .. i prefer my mac salad just a touch on the sweet side so add 2 packets of splenda ... next time I am going to try it cutting the mustard back too.

Display Name:
JACKRBIKE

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Superb recipe, not at all like the purchased salads. Always a hit at gatherings. Have made this several times, experimenting here and there.  My only final changes are to use fresh red pepper for color, and to omit the salt the recipe specifies, as I salt (1.5T) the water I cook the pasta in. Then, if needed, I salt to taste as a final step!

Now, the only refinements are: (1) use 1/2 green pepper and 1/2 red pepper for color; (2) no pimento; (3) chop onion very very finely, almost like minced, to retain flavor while hiding onion bite from anti-onion-chunks folk; (4) celery and pepper are sliced and chopped into chunks no larger than frozen peas.  

Using eggs makes so little difference I have dispensed with that variation, unless I feel there's a need for protein.  The excessive sweetness that some reviewers comment on pretty much disappears if the pasta is refrigerated for several hours or overnight.  Try the recipe first before you cut the sugar! As an added tip, I have found apple cider vinegar to be helpful in this recipe if I have it available.

I use weight instead of volume where possible.  Four cups elbows weigh 22 oz, so, using the convenient one pound box gives you a surplus of sauce.  Four cups of rings weigh slightly under 16 oz.  Four of ditallini weigh 19.6 oz. My point?  Depending on the pasta used (and its surface area), the "creaminess" of the sauce will vary.  Nonetheless, you'll be happy regardless of what one-pound pasta box you use, or if you use volume.

This recipe was very good!  I did change things up a bit to suit my families likes.  I left out the celery, green pepper, carrots and pimentos. text:
This was an easy, fantastic recipe. I made it for a cookout, and it got rave reviews. I loved it so much I made another batch the very next day! For my version, I used cider vineager instead of white, a scant 2/3 cup of sugar, and added 2 tablespoons of sour cream. The dressing is very runny at first, but it gets thicker in the fridge overnight. For best results, I recommend making it a full 24 hours before you plan to eat it. Delicious!

This is a very, very good salad. I did change a few things though. Miracle Whip instead of mayonnaise, cider vinegar instead of white, cut back to 1/3 cup of sugar and added about 1/3 cup of sweet pickle relish, 4 hard boiled eggs and maybe a little more black pepper. I have shared this with a few others and they say it's the best macaroni salad they have ever eaten! Thanks for sharing this recipe!!!

text:
This is the best macaroni salad I have ever eaten.  I have made it several times now but somehow keep forgetting to rate it!  The thing I love the best about this recipe is that it is not swimming in mayo.  Too many macaroni/potato salads are and I don't care for them at all.  The only thing I change is to cut down on the sugar a bit.  It's fine with the full amount but just a little too sweet for my taste.  Also, it tastes even better if you make it the day before you plan on serving it.  So yummy!

text:
A great recipe for a basic, old-fashioned macaroni salad.  I used small penne for the pasta because I had a lot leftover from some Italian pasta recipe I had made. Also, I omitted the chopped celery, but used a few shakes of celery seed instead. Mix the dressing ingredients separately and CUT BACK ON THE SUGAR, and a bit less on the mustard and salt too.  I used minced Vidala onion. We really enjoyed this macaroni salad.  The bonus is that it's a lot less work that the Amish macaroni salad I usually make from the recipe on this site.

text:
This was excellent! I took the advice of countless other reviews and used a little less than 1/4 cup of sugar, added some hard-boiled eggs and also backed off a little bit on the amount of vegetables. I also made it the night before our party and made another batch of the dressing (minus the veggies) and let it sit in the fridge overnight as well. The pasta will soak up a lot so having the extra dressing to mix in before serving is almost neccessary. Was a big hit with my family.

text:
This is the second time I have made this salad in the past month and have made adjustments to the original recipe. I scaled the pasta down to two cups but kept the dressing the same; the macaroni does soak up some of the mayo mixture but doubling it makes it perfect when refrigerated! I used 1/3 cup + 2 tbsp. of sugar instead of the 2/3 cup, added two hardboiled eggs, 2 stalks of celery, and a bell pepper.  Great, easy recipe!  I'm looking forward to trying this with potatoes next time.

This is really a great recipe!  But - you really need to chill this well to get the best taste. I found 4 hours wasn't enough - it tasted good but seemed a little sweet.  After 10-12 hours, the sweetness had mellowed and the salad was great!  It was a wonderful cross between a traditional mac salad creamy dressing and a slaw dressing.  We made a triple recipe and they scraped the bowl!

country:
None
text:
Will definitely make this again.  Just a couple of changes, but nothing major as this is a very good base recipe.  I didn't rinse the macaroni, but let it cool to room temperature, stirring occasionally. This lets starch build up, which allows the dressing to stick to the pasta better. I also used Dijon mustard rather than plain, and cut the sugar by 1/4. This is a really good base recipe which can be tweaked and created with whatever vegetables and/or pasta you have on hand, and the dressing is easily adjusted for personal taste.

text:
I wasn't sure how to rate this recipe because on one hand it is the exact macaroni salad recipe I was looking for but I did have to make a couple of changes to the recipe.  So, I'm rating the recipe a 3 before the changes and a 5 after the changes I made.  It seemed like the recipe called for way too much sugar for my taste, so I changed the amount to 2 tablespoons and that made the sweetness just right.  Also, I decreased the salt and added just 1 teaspoon.  And instead of 1 whole onion I added about 1/4 of a purple onion.  Once I made these changes the recipe was fantastic.  The vegetables are crunchy and the flavor just right.

text:
Tried this recipe 3 times.  

As is, way too sweet!
It's perfect if you cut the sugar to 1/3 cup, even 1/4 cup.  Increase the pepper by 1 teaspoon.  Just remember that if its too sweet add pepper.

Last adjustment was that I added diced roasted red pepper and not the optional pimento.  You can get that canned or skip it all together.   

Another tip is to only use green bell pepper. Red,  yellow and orange will only add to the sweetness.

text:
Really liked this recipe for macaroni salad. I followed a few of the other reviewers' tips: cut the sugar down to 1/4 cup and used 1/2 TB less mustard. I also added some frozen mixed veggies, shredded cheddar cheese, and bacon bits - my family loved it! The following day, I added some tuna and served it over some Romaine lettuce, and it made a nice little lunch :) I could never really find a good recipe for a classic macaroni salad (without all the fancy ingredients or things I didn't have on hand), but this one is a keeper! Next, I'll try it for a potato salad :)

text:
I don't cook much and have never made a macaroni salad before. After finding this recipe it sounded easy enough and I wouldn't have to go to the store for anything. I cut the serving size down to 4 since 10 would be way too much for my little family. I added 5 grape tomatoes sliced up and cubed cheddar cheese. Everything else was as the recipe states for serving 4 people. My kids are pretty picky as they are 1 and 4, but they ate some of it. My husband thought it was one of the best things I've made and I myself thought it was pretty yummy. I did think the sugar content was a little too much, so maybe I'd cut that back next time. Otherwise, this recipe was really good. We even had left overs after dinner which is good because I'd definitely eat it again. Thanks for this quick and easy recipe! :)

text:
My husband and I both loved this. It was not too sweet at all. I think the mustard balances it out nicely. I made it exactly as described, but I think next time I will add more mayo to the dressing so it is creamier and add the dressing to chilled noodles. By letting it sit in the refrigerator for several hours the noodles absorbed the dressing and made it a tad dry. Flavor was spot on, but just not creamy enough. Otherwise a total winner in our house!

country:

text:
I followed some suggestions from other reviewers and used 1/4 cup sugar, garlic salt instead of regular salt, and added paprika (which turned the dish orange XD). I accidentally added too much vinegar, so I had to put in a lot more mayo. I taste tested it before sticking it in the fridge so it'd be ready for this evening's Thanksgiving feast, and it's okay. It's probably because I accidentally let the bottle of vinegar "glug" by tipping it over too much, but in any case 2 tablespoons seems like an awful lot. If you like a mild macaroni salad, cut the vinegar in half or use 1.5 tablespoons. Taste it before adding the full amount.

Note: I cut the recipe yield in half. Four cups of uncooked pasta is an awful lot.

country:
None
text:
I really liked this macaroni salad recipe, the pasta didn't dry out and it makes a good basic side dish.  I didn't add any celery or pimentos, and only half an onion (around here we're a bit iffy on raw onion and we don't like celery).  With the sugar I noticed that others had complained it was too sweet, so I just added it spoonful by spoonful into the dressing base until I was happy with the taste, although it was way less than 2/3c.  I did use half regular mustard and half Dijon, I'm running out of both so I just made it up to the right amount.  I didn't grate the carrot and I added 2 in total, and half a capsicum just because we had it.  It's a very versatile base macaroni salad recipe.

text:
I made the recipe just about exactly as stated. I did add the optional carrots. I used red bell pepper instead of the green because that's what I had on hand. I added cut up hard boiled eggs. I've never made macaroni salad with the sugar and vinegar because it didn't sound good. Those two items were the key!!! This was the best macaroni salad I've ever made or had. It wasn't too sweet like I saw on some reviews. It was great! Everyone in my family loved it. Note- Make sure you put it in the frig for the 4 hours like it states. When you make it and mix it together it will be very runny. I thought I messed up the recipe. After the 4 hours in the frig is was perfect!

I'm only rating the mayo mix for this recipe because, let's face it people,  the add-ins you use do not matter. I used pickles, eggs, shallots, ham and cheese because that's what I had, but anything will work--throw it in there. The mayo mix is really good and is sweet but it is meant to be that way obviously.  The portion of mayo to pasta is right, it wasn't too dry or too runny.  I'm saving this one.

I had never made macaroni salad before but I promised myself that on this July 4th I would not settle for bland supermarket macaroni salad! I read the reviews and used less vinegar and sugar but otherwise followed the recipe faithfully.  I thought the end result was a little salty for my taste (I tend not to use a lot of salt in food) so I added 4 boiled eggs.  It was truly delicious. I can't wait to have some more tomorrow and see how much better it tastes.  Thank you for a great recipe. I will never buy macaroni salad from store again.

text:
Fantastic when made with only 1/8 - 1/4 c of sugar!  The whole family loved it and it reminded me of macaroni salads of my youth.  The dressing is perfect in taste and was just the right amount for the amount of pasta.  I made it 6hrs ahead of being served so the dressing had absorbed into the pasta, which is just the way we like it.  My family doesn't like salads that are very saucy or have too much dressing.  The only variations I made from the original recipe was reduce the sugar to less than 1/4 c and a little more than 1/8c.  I also didn't have any macaroni noodles on hand so I used multicolored rotini spirals. I wasn't sure they would work okay with this kind of a dressing since I normally use Italian dressing with those, but it turned out fantastic.  I really liked the shredded carrots in the salad.  I have never thought to add them to a cold salad, but they really worked well.  I think this salad would work well with other additions like some thawed frozen green peas.

text:
Ok, so this is delicious. I'm a poor college kid, so it was nice to be able to make something out of stuff that you typically just have laying around. I don't like peppers, and my carrots had gone bad, so I left those out. Also, I'm not big on onions and pepper, so I added half of the onion, and maybe about half of the pepper (I put it straight in the mix from the grater without measuring, so I'm not for sure). Oh, yeah, and I used rotini pasta. It definitely would have been better if it had more vegetables besides the celery and onion, but I still loved it. I've been craving macaroni salad for a week, and this definitely took care of that! Next time I might try adding broccoli or radishes, but we usually have some assortment of vegetables around my apartment, so it's nice to know that I'll be able to whip this up whenever I feel like it!

This was very easy and VERY yummy!  I made it without celery, carrot, and pimento peppers because I didn't have them on hand.  Next time, I will cut down on the sugar just because it was a bit too sweet for my hubby.  I'm thinking of cutting the vinegar, as well, because it has quite a bite afterwards.  But, I will definitely be making this again!  Thanks!

text:
I was searching for a classic mac salad and came across this recipe.  It did not disappoint.  I have to say I am not a huge mustard fan, and was a bit worried to see my mixture turn yellow, but it blended nicely with the rest of the ingredients and was not overpowerful.  

Make sure you chill this the night ahead, as it is much better the next day.  This was a huge hit at my BBQ.  Enjoy.

text:
Wow, I couldn't stop eating this salad.  Definitely adjust to your taste.  I read other reviews and only added 1/4c of the sugar and also cut the vinegar by half.  I don't really like the idea of putting so much mustard so I only put 1tsp in mine.  My guests asked for the recipe. This is a salad you want to make a day before so that the dressing is not so runny.  Once it cools, it's creamy and delicious. Loved it--will make again and again.

text:
I think this is one of the best recipes I have ever tried.  I gave it 4 stars because of the sugar. I only put 1/3 of a cup of sugar and it was still a little sweet for me.  I made it an hour before supper and it was still wonderful but the next day it was fantastic and the sweetness had been absorbed by the macaroni..  I used red bell peppers instead of green because that was what I had.  If you can let it sit overnight for the next day. It was still very creamy and not dry like most of my pasta salads are the next day.

text:
I had been craving macaroni salad because I love the macaroni salad I get at Hawaiian BBQ's. This was extremely similar. I omitted all the veggies mainly because I do not like crunch at all in my macaroni salad (texture issue). Instead of the onion, I added green onion (no crunch and not as strong onion flavor), and I only had apple cider vinegar on hand, so I used that. I ended up eating some at dinner and it was great, but I had some for lunch the next day and it was AWESOME. This definately tastes better the next day. Yummy!! Very similar to Hawaiian BBQ's as well.

userID:
2084159
Display Name:
Nikolette T
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
61
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/393118.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yes Yes Yes! This is a great Macaroni Salad base recipe to work from. I think everyone has their own ideas about how sweet or tart they like their food and as such should start with half the sugar and vinegar and add more as desired but remember that the flavors will get bolder as the salad sits. Especially the sweetness. I used just under the called-for amount of sugar and about half the vinegar because my boyfriend isn't fond of too much zestiness in food. I omitted the green pepper since we were out and the pimento since I do not care for them. I used a smaller onion and diced it instead of chopping it so there weren't large chunks of onions in it. I also added more celery and grated a couple of small-medium carrots into it to make up for the lack of pimento. Any time I can get away with adding more carrots or celery to a dish I always do for the nutritional value it adds. I also used a little less mustard and some ground celery seed (like celery salt but without the salt!). I sliced sweet grape tomatoes in half and cubed some mild cheddar cheese, each about half a cup. Probably more like 2/3 on the cheese but I just eyeballed it.   I can hardly wait to eat this as a side with brisket in a couple days. I'm sure I'll have some for lunch tomorrow since it is so good. My boyfriend who typically doesn't care for many of the ingredients on their own, or raw, etc also really enjoyed this. I used mini penne instead of macaroni and I must say it looks a lot nicer.

text:
Love this recipe!  I have made it several times now, both exactly as written and with a few modifications. I add chopped boiled egg because it just doesn't seem like macaroni salad without it. And I cut the sugar in half because I like a little less sweetness. Once, after I had already started making it, I realized that I was almost out of plain yellow mustard so I used half yellow mustard and half spicy brown. Worked out great. But I have gotten lots of compliments either way. You won't go wrong with this recipe!

text:
This salad tasted pretty good. It was very easy to prepare and took very little time. The only thing I wasn't sure about was the amount of sugar because lots of reviewers said it was too much but a few reviewers also said after being left overnight it was just sweet enough. So I compromised by using less than originally called for in the recipe but also a bit more than just half the amount. It came out a bit too sweet so next time I will just use half the amount of sugar. Aside from this the recipe was really good. I had used ziti because that's what I had and it still came out good. Tasted just like the macaroni salads I had previously at parties and restaurants.

text:
I was really impressed with this recipe!  It was very flavorful even though we started in on it early (after one hour instead of four).  I mostly followed the recipe; as other reviewers suggested, I added some frozen peas (nuked for 2 minutes with a little water, because I forgot to drop them in with the pasta for a minute's worth of boiling), cubed cheddar, and sunflower seeds.  Also, when I made the dressing, I used white wine vinegar (it was what I had, plus it has more flavor than white distilled) and added sugar to taste (honestly, probably only a tablespoon or two).  I halved the recipe, so that could have affected the ultimate outcome, but one of the things that I really liked about this salad was that it wasn't super mayonnaise-y.  The dressing was just enough to moisten it without making it heavy.  Excellent!

text:
This recipe was really good and different than most macaroni salad I have made.  You get both a tangy and sweet taste from the sauce.   I did reduce the sugar by about 1-1/2 tablespoons.  DEFINITELY refrigerate overnight.  I served it after 4 hours being refrigerated and the sauce was runny and didn't cling to the macaroni.  It wasn't very good the first night.  The next day the sauce was thick - clung to the macaroni and was perfect.  What a difference! I guess the extra time helped the macaroni absorb some of the sauce.  Next time I'll probably add some small chunks of cheddar.

userID:
2172073
Display Name:
PHXie

46

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made it with Miracle Whip, which made it far too zesty. I added some cheddar cheese and Ranch dressing to tone it down. Did not have green pepper, but added frozen peas (rinsed in a colander to thaw). After 6 hours in the fridge, the flavor had mellowed and everybody loved it.

The second time I followed the recipe, including using regular mayonnaise. I liked the Ranch dressing and cheddar cheese, so I added them again. Also diced some ham and tossed that in.

Made it a couple more times and followed the recipe exactly. Making it again today, but with a bit less mustard and sugar, as that is what I prefer.

This is a great recipe that can be easily tweaked according to your tastes and what you have on hand. For best flavor and consistency, be sure to 1) let the sauce-veggie mix "mellow" in the fridge for at least a couple of hours and 2) not mix the sauce into the pasta until an hour or so before serving.

text:
Great basic macaroni salad recipe has just the right amount of tart/sweetness to it.  It really does improve if left for 24 hours.  I always like to tone down my onion a bit so if I don't have a sweet onion I use a regular onion and dice it up small for the salad then soak the diced onion in cold water for 1/2 hour before adding to the recipe it will calm down the flavor of the onion.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is basically like my own recipe, except with about 1/2 the amount of sugar, and I use Miracle Whip plus diced hard-boiled eggs.  But what I do when I make macaroni or potato salad is I mix up the vinegar, sugar, salt, pepper and yellow mustard and add it to the hot macaroni or potatoes and refrigerate it for a couple of hours or overnight.  This gets more flavor into the macaroni or potatoes.  Also if your dressing seems a little dry, try adding a splash of milk.  At family reunions, etc., my kids would only eat my salads.

text:
My husband and I really enjoyed this.  It's definitely the vinegar that gives this the right "tang".  I found it tasty even before waiting the "4 hours" before eating.  The sugar is necessary to offset the vinegar which can be overpowering to anyone not used to the sourness.  I added the sugar a tsp at a time after everything was mixed until it "cut" the strong taste of the vinegar.

text:
I feel pretty silly reviewing this recipe with all the changes/additions that I made.  This is what I did:  basically 1/2 mayo & 1/2 sour cream, 1/2 yellow mustard & 1/2 dijon; green onion instead of regular; added sliced green olives and shredded cheddar (small amount).  Did not use bell pepper (husband's preference).  I also reduced the amount of sugar by about 1/3.  For what it's worth, everything else was the same. Nevertheless, we just loved it, my husband is hogging the leftovers!

This is my favorite macaroni salad recipe.  Just how my Nanny used to fix it.  My only advice is to make this a day ahead as all the flavors need to soak into the macaroni.  If it is a tad bit dry the next day just add a little milk and stir!  I do omit peppers and carrots although I am sure they are good in the salad if you like them.

text:
This is a very forgiving recipe.  After reading the reviews, here are the changes I made:
used Mircle Whip instead of Mayo. Cut sugar in half.  Used four boiled eggs.  Reduced the onion to 1/2 cup finely shopped red onion. Reduced the Mustard to 1 generous Tablespoon.  As other folks suggested, I mixed in only 1/2 of the dressing.  Refrigerated overnight.  The next day, before my guests arrived, added the remainder dressing.  Yummy!

text:
I had a hankering for some macaroni salad and happened on this recipe.  It looked like a good place to start, of course, I made a few variations:  1). Some reviewers thought it was too sweet so I cut the sugar by half.  Turns out 1/3 cup is sweet enough for me.  2).  I used cider vinegar instead of distilled.  3).  I used Miracle Whip for the dressing.  4).  I used a couple of fresh Red Fresno peppers for the pimento.  5).  I added 1 pound of grated sharp cheddar cheese.  I did put carrot in it so the result is more orange than most macaroni salad.  Does not matter to me -- it's good and it will become part of my repertoire.  I am not much of a cook and it is great to have another yummy dish I can make!

text:
This is a pretty good recipe overall.  I read a lot of the reviews and it seems that the main problem with the recipe is the sweetness so I added the sugar last and did so by a tablespoon at a time.  I'm glad I did because 2/3 cup would be way way way too much. I estimate that I used about 2 Tbsp  and it turned out pretty good - everyone loved it. Frankly I don't think sugar is needed at all in this recipe. I always leave out the pimento and carrot and use red bell peppers instead of green . You could also reduce the vinegar a bit.

Display Name:
TURTLE BAY
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My daughter & I have made this macaroni salad many times.  This time I watched CHEF JOHN'S recipe and combined both recipes.  I used cavatappi macaroni (it's a little fancier than elbows.)  I used a Vidalia onion (sweeter than regular onion), white pepper, 1Tbsp. of sugar and a little garlic powder.  I omitted the jalapeno and poblano peppers.  The major difference I found from watching the video was  not to rinse the macaroni and to allow it to cool
completely and to NOT mix it with oil to separate.  It needs to be sticky and stick to your hands per CHEF JOHN.  Also after cooling & dressing the salad, cover it with the plastic wrap directly on the macaroni.  This was a FANTASTIC salad & thanks to CHEF JOHN for his expertise suggestion.  I will DEFINITELY make this again & again.  Thanks also to GRADEN for the basic recipe.  Now if I can only find a great potato salad recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my favorite crown pleasing recipe base I have ever used- like most I also make small changes- First change is less sugar- unless you are used to Hawaiian mac salad and like it sweet! Then I tried it with the new "spicy" yellow mustard- very nice! Also I either cut the macaroni in half or double the dressing, depending on how many I will be feeding- If made as directed and left to sit over night in the fridge, which makes it taste better, the dressing gets completely soaked up. So I reserve half and mix in before serving (after I double it). If I have I also chop some radish for color- or use red peppers as well. I have also mixed in some small cubed cheddar cheese just before serving!

text:
My family recipe called for one seeded and finely chopped tomato, but not pimento,sugar, or vinegar. The mayonaise seemed to have seasoning enough. For those who do not like - or have handy - any celery - a dash of celery seed works well. After draining the macaroni, I sprinkle with just a tiny dash of olive oil (perhaps 1/2 teaspoon) and stir thoroughly to keep the pasta from clumping. I also add the onions immediately, while the macaroni is hot, so that maximum flavor is absorbed.

I thought this recipe was awesome! I had about 2 cups of elbow macaroni and 2 1/2 cups left of rotini and decided to make this. I made additional adjustments to the sauce: I used a little less than 1/2 cup of the sugar, added 1 tbsp of apple cider vinegar, 1 1/2 tbsp of sweet relish, 1 tbsp of lemon juice, 1/2 tsp of dill, 1 tsp of celery seeds and stirred the sauce with all the other ingredients listed. It was delicious! Creamy and tangy, with just the right amount of sweet! Definitely a keeper! Thank you Graden for sharing!

text:
I am giving it 5 stars because this is the classic recipe for mac salad, but it has way too much sugar.  I have been making this for so long I do the "pinch" method and add what is probably around two tablespoons or so.  I just eyeball it.  I want just enough sweetness to work w/the tart of the vinegar.

I do love JqSmith's idea of making the dressing a day ahead of time for the flavors to meld and then adding it to the pasta the next day.  From now on that is how I will do it.

text:
I was looking for a cold macaroni salad recipe for the extra macaroni left-over when I made Mac and Cheese the other day. This one has a great base sauce - I gave it 4 stars - but I modified it slightly and it's delicious! I reduced the sugar to 1/4 c, reduced the mustard to 1 Tablespoon and the onion to 1/2 of a large onion. I completely omitted the celery, carrot, bell pepper and pimiento. Instead, I added 5 slices crisp, cooked bacon (crumbled), a bit of garlic powder (about 1/2 teaspoon) and one can petite diced tomato (drained). Going back for seconds now...

text:
My daughter came home recently from having dinner with her boyfriend's family begging me to make Macaroni Salad like his Mom had made. I am a terrible cook! So allrecipes.com has become my lifesaver. She didn't particularly like this the first time I served it so we began to tweek and learn. We add 2 Tablespoons of Sweet Relish and 1 Cup of Cole Slaw Dressing. I also leave out the green peppers just because our family doesn't care for them and I cut back on the vinegar by about 1/2. Definitely refrigerate over night. I served it straight after making the first time and I think that was the major reason my daughter didn't like it. But this one has definitely made it into the family recipe file.

text:
I make pasta salads about once a month.  I was craving something traditional after making so many "fancier" pasta salads.  This hit the spot.  Like others, I reduced the sugar to 1/4 cup, a little less vinegar, and added 1/3 cup sour cream to make it creamier.  You can add whatever vegetables you have on hand.  I used 1/2 a yellow onion, 1/2 red pepper, 1/2 green pepper, peas, 3 boiled eggs, and cubed cheese.  Really hit the spot for what I was craving!

Tried this recipe for the 4th of July 2014, It is amazing. Just as it is. I was kind of hesitant because of some of the reviews stating it was too sweet. It good just as it is. Understanding we all have taste buds that react to different taste in different ways. So I will only say how my taste buds reacted and I love it. Even my nine years old who hates everything loved it. I kinda was nervous because of the celery and onions which she hates, she watched me make it and was saying no mom no onions and no celery, but I wanted to make it as the recipe called for at least. So if I didn't like it I would adjust the next time. All my guests loved it and wanted the recipe. Next time I may make it as it is on the recipe but add shrimp, or crab meat, or maybe chicken. Glad I foud this recipe. It beats my old favorite by miles. Taste better than my old favorite from the deli. There's a new mac salad in town for this family.

After dumping in the 2/3 cup sugar, I read the comments and realized this was probably a mistake. If you did this, not to worry! Just add an extra 1/2 cup mayo, 2 more celery stalks, an extra (red) onion and green pepper, 2 more cups of pasta, and sprinkle garlic powder and paprika liberally. That is what I did and I think it turned out great.

text:
I prepare a very similar recipe all the time, especially in summer months, and it is always a hit with family and friends.  I add cheddar cheese, cut into small cubes, and normally do not add onion or carrots (as a personal choice).  Other than that, recipe is the same!!!  I do find that on the 2nd or 3rd day, if there's any left, you have to add a bit more mayonnaise to keep it moist!!  If you haven't tried this one, it's definitely one to  add to the top of your list!!!

text:
This is wonderful!  This makes a huge salad so look out!  I cut down the sugar to 1/3 cup, added pimentos and about 1/2 cup of chopped cheddar cheese (very small chunks, about 1/4").  The salad complemented a Thai Red Curry dish I served for dinner.  Plenty of salad left over, which I don't mind a bit!!!  This recipe is so simple and definitely a keeper.  Thanks for sharing Graden!!!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2244417.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not sure how "classic" this is but it has a good foundation for greatness.  I liked the addition of sugar, though I reduced the amount to 1/3 cup.  It rendered a delicate sweetness, and balanced well with the other ingredients.  There was definitely something missing, so I added 3 hard cooked eggs as others suggested, sliced black olives, and cooked green peas.  I also suggest using green onions as they have more flavor.  Personally I don't like bell pepper in my mac salad, so I omitted it.  The dressing stays nice and keeps the pasta moist in the salad, with no need to add anything else prior to serving.  Great for potlucks.

text:
I was curious about the amount of sugar, so I decided to try this to see if it worked.  It did not.  The sugar was overpowering, making the dressing more fitting for a fruit salad than a standard picnic standby.  I remade the recipe, and dropped the sugar to 1 Tablespoon.  It turned out just fine.  I would maybe go 2 tablespoons if you hae a particularly sweet tooth.
As for the rest of the recipe with less sugar, this turns out a very standard, expectable, maccaroni salad.  It isn't particuarly spectacular or memorable.  It would do, but just isn't all that memorable.

text:
I wanted to make a different side so I chose this to try, everyone loved it.  The only thing I did wrong was, the recipe called for 4 cups macaroni, so I brought 2, 16oz. boxes of macaroni.  I didn't realize the once one box of macaroni cooked it would equal 4 cups, so I had to add more ingrediants.  Just wanted to put that in my rating in case there were others that didn't know that too.

text:
I have never made a traditional macaroni salad before but this turned out fantastic.  I did make a few changes due to what I had on hand.  I didn't have yellow mustard so I used spicy brown, I was low on yellow onion so I used red, and I was all out of green bell pepper, but I had a very small jar of pimentos, so I added those.  I think these were minor changes so I know the original recipe is solid.  If you like spicy brown mustard on your sandwiches I highly recommend it for this recipe, it was wonderful!

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
pretty close to what Mom used to make. I use Miracle Whip instead of mayo, if for no other reason, Miracle Whip can withstand setting out little longer without worrying about spoiling in the heat of the sun on a picnic. I use little less sugar, 1/2 cup is good. Substitute only one tablespoon of prepared horseradish instead of mustard. I also like little more celery, some frozen peas go well in this salad, and maybe some canned meat like Turkey Spam or some other. Adding the meat can make this dish a meal in itself.

text:
Made for the millionth time. It's great as written but we add less sugar, less mustard and most definitely refrigerate overnight! Also, the following day RESIST THE URGE to add any more Mayo. Just give it all a good stir and your set. When it sets overnight, it absorbs all that goodness and imo you are left with a perfectly made macaroni salad. Not at all too wet or creamy. I think it's perfect! We use one full box (16oz) of pasta for this recipe.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was incredibly delicious! I didn't have elbow pasta, so I used tiny shells. I was getting bored with all the italian dressing and plain mayo style salads. The sweet mustard sauce was the perfect change! It was almost like some honey mustards. It was very addicting. There is a lot of sauce at first, but that is because it hasn't set yet. There is a lot of room to play and perfect it to your taste, so there really shouldn't be any negative reviews. In fact, I don't like raw, crunchy veggies in my cold salads, so I steamed mine first. It's all preference. Add ingredients, remove, change quantity. Just play with it. I know I will. But my DH loves it too, so either way, this is a keeper for my house!

text:
My daughter, who thought she didn't like macaroni salad, tasted the dressing before I added the macaroni and said it tasted "just like honey mustard, only better" :) And I thought the dressing was exactly what I wouldn't like - I grew up on plain mayonnaise macaroni salad. My family doesn't like peppers or pimentos, and I didn't have celery, so mine was simple with just carrots but it was DELICIOUS! We ate it all in one sitting but next time I'll make sure it sits overnight - I can tell the flavors would have been even better if we'd waited. I'll make this a LOT this summer!

I have modified this a little . I use a little less vinegar, 1/2 tablespoons less on the mustard, 1/2 large onion,  minced 5 large carrots and a half of a large cabbage in an immersion blender. Use also the diced pimentos in a jar. Taste better the next day. Can use the whole onion if eaten the next day because the strong onion taste is neutralized  and does not taste as strong.

Made this for Father's Day cookout the night before.  I reserve some of the dressing.  The morning of, add the rest of the dressing (to coat) and veggies, because I think they stay crisper.  You can, obviously, add or omit whatever veggies you like.  I add broccoli, cukes and red and yellow pepper.  Omit the onion and celery, as I'm not a fan.  My favorite of several pasta salad recipes I have.

This is the macaroni salad recipe I have used for years, just did not have a reference point as to dressing amounts. I made as stated, it was a bit dry and then made it again.Added 1/4 cup more mayo and 2 more tbs. of vinegar. Omitted the green pepper, imo it overtakes the other flavors. Also used sliced green olives instead of pimentos. My mom uses this recipe and adds sliced hard boiled eggs.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7458916.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We really liked this recipe.  It is a very good, basic recipe that you can trust.  I did find it to be just a little bland, so I kicked it up myself just a tad to make it more flavorful.  The changes I made were to double the sauce, add about 8 eggs, diced, cut back on the sugar some (I don't care for things to be too sweet.)  I also don't like a lot of crunchy things in my mac salads so I cut the onion back to about 1/4 cup.  To make up the difference for flavor, I used a generous sprinkling of onion powder as well as about 1/2 tsp. of celery seed.  Also, used more mustard than it calls for.  It sounds like a lot of changes, but they were very minor.  I would just sprinkle until i liked what it tasted like.  I will def. make this again.  Also, we had some left over cooked shrimp, and it was very refreshing to eat as a main dish salad.

None
text:
I made this before Hurricane Irene knowing we'd want food that could be eaten cold in coming days. I just used the ingredients we had, so onion and green peppers (no celery, no carrot or pimento peppers). It seems very versatile and would work well with lots of different variations.

I made the dressing almost exactly - I substituted apple cider vinegar for white because that's what I had. 

I was a little worried it was a bit sweet and mustardy but in the end it came out really well. Everyone loved it! So, it was quick and easy and was enjoyed by all.

I will definitely be making again and playing with different vegetables to include and maybe a bit less sugar. A fantastic recipe to have as a basic for barbqs etc.

I usually shy away from macaroni salad because it is often bland or just tastes like mayo.  Not the case here!  I did cut the sugar in half though and it was plenty sweet.  I used white ground pepper as opposed to black and yellow bell pepper, not green (what I had in the fridge).  I did add the grated carrot and put relish in place of the pimento.  I made the dressing the night before and mixed it with the cooked macaroni the day of my BBQ.  It was a hit!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This is a very tasty recipe.  Here is the only thing I changed simply for preference only:

-No celery, pimentos and I added some frozen sweet peas.

As for changes I felt were needed, the dressing tastes great, but as others said I used only 1/4 cup sugar and I think more was needed to give it a creamier texture.  So I used the exact same ingredients in the dressing, but just used 1.5 times the amount listed.  So instead of 1 cup mayo, it was 1.5 cups, sugar instead of my scaled down 1/4 cup I used .375 cups(1/4 * 1.5)  etc.....  Will make again, probably today in fact!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Macaroni salad is traditionally a sweeter salad than other pasta salads. That being said I thought this was really good, but I did tweak it a little. I cut way down on the onion, to around a 1/4 cup (personal preference!), and like others I cut down on the sugar and added some sweet relish. I didn't have any green peppers so I cut up some baby carrots for extra crunch, and added 3 boiled eggs at the suggestion of other reviewers. I also put in a small jar of pimento stuffed olives because I love them. I added the celery too and the result was delicious! Everyone has different tastes and tweaks recipes accordingly, but had I made this following the recipe to a T I'm sure it would have been just as good!

text:
This truly is the perfect, classic macaroni salad. Like other reviewers I cut the sugar; with about 1/8 cup sugar the flavors were perfectly balanced. Don't worry if it seems like too much mustard at first, just trust the recipe! It looks very yellow after it's mixed, and if you taste it right after mixing the mustard flavor will seem very up-front--but let it sit overnight and it will be perfect. I made this for a family party and everyone love-love-loved it! This will be my go-to recipe for macaroni salad from now on.

text:
I have made it twice...first as directed, but used a red bell pepper instead of green since no one in my family cares for them and deleting the chopped pimento, and because I had it, a RED onion.....it was "ok". Not a fan of that sweet/tart taste. I had one child who detested it and one child who loved it. The other kids were "so-so" with it. The next time I made it, I completely cut out both the vinegar and the sugar and instead of using 2 1/2 tbsp of yellow mustard, I used 1/4 cup honey mustard dipping sauce (I use Kents brand). I left everything else the same like I did before.  Everyone, ALL my kids loved it.  I think the shredded carrots, celery, red onion, red pepper and cucumber gives it a beautiful color contrast and yummy crunch.

Good salad but ill only make it again when im looking for something different that my usual.

text:
I love this salad and so does the hubby.  I make it in big batches just to eat over several days myself!  I only gave 4 stars instead of 5 because I cautioned and went with reviews to cut down the sugar.  I used exactly half of what it called for.  I figured if it wasn't sweet enough then I could always add in, but not take out.  It was perfect with just half the sugar. Also, I like my mac salads fairly creamy and this is just enough to coat (once it sits and soaks in).  So if you are like me, then do 1 1/2 or double the sauce for the recipe.  But even as is it tastes great. We're a big fan of olives and eggs in our mac salad, so at the end I added those in too.

text:
I followed the dressing recipe exactly but just added garlic powder and paprika.  I used different vegetables since we aren't huge fans of the ones listed.  I used garden tomato, sliced black olives, and green onion.  I also added 4 hard boiled eggs, chopped.  When serving, I add chopped up hard salami and a little bit of fresh dill to make a complete lunch and the kids loved it!  As recommended by others, over-night refridgeration is a must and it really does cut down the sweetness, making it a perfect macaroni salad...and I usually don't even like macaroni salad!  Thank you for an easy, cheap, and yummy summer dish!

text:
I tried this recipe for the first time last night to bring to a bbq today. When I checked on the salad this morning the taste was delicious, BUT it was absolutely DRY DRY DRY. If you are going to make this recipe try tripling the mayo and mustard and almost doubling the vinegar. Or you could cut the pasta in half (which might be better if you are just making for your own family). This recipe made an overflowing aluminum disposable tray worth of food! So I would say use the recipe its tasty but make your life easy and use these adjustments so that the pasta stays moist and delicious!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe “as is” and again with some changes mentioned by others. The amount of sugar called for in this recipe, made it simply inedible. And the prepared yellow mustard made it too tangy and not at all aesthetically pleasing. Unless you’re feeding Martians who may appreciate a neon-yellow salad, try using Grey Poupon Dijon Mustard instead of the prepared yellow mustard. The taste is much more sophisticated and blends much better.  I also added a bit of Paprika and an extra stalk of celery.   With the changes, this is an excellent recipe.

text:
I grew up in New York, and practically lived on deli macaroni salad.  Since moving a few years ago, I've tried numerous macaroni salad recipes and have been consistently disappointed.  This is the closest thing to deli style macaroni salad I've found yet - it's a hit with the whole family!  To everyone saying it's too sweet - you have to let it sit for the recommended time.  Even after 2 hours the sweetness settles down.  It seemed soooooo sweet and a bit runny at first, but after letting it set in the fridge for a couple of hours, I can't keep my mom from sneaking in 'just to try it'!

text:
I have made this macaroni salad now 3 times. While I feared, when first making it, that it may be too sweet, I elected to make it exactly as the recipe called for, except for adding 2 or 3 boiled eggs and a bit of sweet pickle relish. I also sprinkle the top of the finished salad with hungarian paprika. (It makes a lovely presentation that way.) Surprisingly, my family loved the salad and everyone who ate it loved it. No one found it too sweet at all. I have abandoned my old macaroni salad recipe in lieu of this one which my family and guests love. I would recommend it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this again today and it tastes wonderful.  I did not have the fresh green pepper; although, I do in the freezer but I was only making a half recipe for myself as my husband does not like macaroni salad and it is just the two of us.  I used hot dog relish instead of yellow mustard as I am out of that as well.  Other than that, I did the same as the recipe instructs with the exception of something I always do with pastas.  If you reserve just a little of the starchy cooking water from the macaroni and add it to the sauce and macaroni it will help to "marry" the sauce to the pasta and makes the texture so much  more like a salad.  Not everyone my prefer this but I do this to all my pasta dishes.

I love this recipe with my changes.  I served this at a huge BBQ Fundraiser.  People were coming back again and again for more.    Here are my changes...I omitted the bell pepper, carrot, and pimentos.  I also changed the amounts of a few things to the following: 2 TB vinegar, 1/3 cup Sugar, 1 TB Yellow Mustard.  I also added 3 TB of Sweet Relish.  And it is a must for this to sit overnight. Great basic recipe!

text:
Love the recipe, made some tweaks that were delicious:  See new recipe here...  2 1/2 cups uncooked tiny shells macaroni 2 1/2 cups radiatore pasta 1/2 cup cup mayonnaise 3/4 cup sour cream 1/4 cup distilled white vinegar 2/3 cup white sugar 2 1/2 tablespoons prepared yellow mustard 1 1/2 teaspoons salt 1/3 teaspoon ground black pepper 1/2 large onion, chopped 2 stalks celery, chopped 1/2 green bell pepper, seeded and chopped 2 cups frozen peas 1/2 dozen baby carrots chopped  This variation was fantastic, and I serve it regularly as a potluck dish at my church.

text:
So yummy! I made a few very minor changes: I used 1lb (uncooked) of bow tie pasta, 1/4 cup sugar only, Grey Poupon Dijon mustard, and red onion. Everything else stayed the same. It was DELICIOUS! It definitely needs to be refrigerated for at least a few hours. It allows all the flavors to come together and absorb into the pasta. I made it for a BBQ party and received many praises. Thank you for this wonderful recipe!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is very similar to a recipe that has been in my family for generations.  As a previous reviewer has done, we also use apple cider vinegar and less sugar.  We tend to use frozen or fresh veggies over canned.    The key to this recipe is to allow it to 'set' - sometimes overnight!  Once the vinegar has a chance to thoroughly permeate all of the ingredients, you end up with a mouthwatering treat.  Additions - Cheese, cubed lunchmeats, any veggie you have on hand!  The more variety of texture you have, the better this is going to be.

Okay, I was not crazy about this recipe ... I like my macaroni salad to be more on the tangy side ... dill pickles and mustard, that kind of thing ... but, my other half absolutely LOVED this recipe ... I followed it exactly ... I thought it was too sweet, but I would ... LOL ... he, on the other hand, thought it was the best macaroni salad he'd ever eaten ... so, that's why I am giving it 5 stars, for him and his sweet tastebuds ... if you like your macaroni salad sweet, you will probably like this ... if not, don't even try it ... thanks!

text:
This salad is exactly what I was looking for.  I needed it for a cookout and it was perfect.  The only change that I made was to use apple cider vinegar since that is all I had.  I used a sweet onion and a couple of shredded baby carrots.  Since everyone had said that the salad really needed to sit overnight but also that it dried out some overnight, I made the dressing the night before and just added the pasta a few hours before the dinner.  That said, that was a few days ago, and I still don't think that the salad is dry.  We're still enjoying it. (It does make a lot!!)

country:
None
text:
This is a pretty good, slightly sweet tasting macaroni salad. My bf (who dislikes creamy pasta salads) liked it, so I guess it's a winner at our house : ) Made a half batch to take to a friend's cookout/football party this weekend. My friends also seemed to like this (which is also a plus, since the last time we got together I made a Ranch potato salad that no one, including me, liked!). I like the texture (i.e. non-creaminess), but, when I think of macaroni salad, I really expect something less "runny". If you are looking for a creamy salad, you may be disappointed. All in all, though, I liked this a lot and would make it again in the future. I did change a couple of things in order to suit my/our tastes (without my changes, I probably wouldn't have liked this as much...). Instead of green pepper, I added a comprable amount of cubed mild cheddar cheese, added some frozen peas and subbed a couple handfulls of shredded carrots (from an 8 oz. package) for the grated carrots called for. Thanks for sharing!

text:
I have been looking for a macaroni salad recipe like this and I was not disappointed.  This salad was great!  I read the reviews before I started, so I decreased the amount of sugar.  I made 1/2 a recipe and used about 1/4 cup of sugar.  I also used a little less mustard.  I used the veggies I had on hand, celery, yellow bell pepper, and I threw in some fresh chives and parsley from the garden.  I didn't use onions, so I added a little onion powder to the dressing since the chives were very mild.  It gets better as it sits, but the 2nd day it was a little dry for my taste so I made some more dressing, and it was perfect.  Next time I will double the dressing.  Thanks for the great recipe!!!

text:
This is a good, easy recipe. I've made it several times over the summer, tweaking it a little differently each time. I've cut the sugar down to 1/4 C., and find that rice wine vinegar gives it an interesting tang - not overpowering, just enough to let you know it's there. Our local Trader Joe's sells canned roasted red peppers & they really give the dish some color and flavor as well.

Display Name:
Teri Carrillo-Fox

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3275223.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best EVER macaroni salad. I don't usually make this, because I don't like mayo-based salads, buy boy am I glad I tried this one! I hosted a family BBQ and this was a HUGE hit with everyone. I love, love, love the sweet and crunchy taste of this salad. Made changes, as follows: decreased mayo to 2/3 c., vinegar to 1/8 c., 1/2 c. sugar, 1/2 Tbsp mustard (don't like mustard), added 1/4 tsp. celery seed and paprika, diced 1/2 red onion and celery, used frozen (thawed) peppers (grn, yellow & red) which I diced, and omitted the pimento. I let it sit in the fridge for about 4 hours before serving. This was even better as leftovers with some diced ham added in for lunch, the next day. YUMMY! I will be making this again and again.

I just made this for July 4th, first time ever making macaroni salad, and everyone really liked it. I did make changes (personal taste), I used the mayo that is made with olive oil (lower fat)and added eggs, pickles, carrots, grated cheese and made the sauce the night before then added it right before we ate it so it would be creamier, hubby said he would even of like more sauce on it. I did not add all the sugar, just didn't seem right, or the peppers or celery, I forgot to buy pimentos, or I would have added them. This is a great recipe to make your own, the sauce is great, then just add your ingredients to your own taste.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very good recipe for tasty macaroni salad. Choose your onion carefully. I had Spanish (yellow) onion on hand and thought one large would be a lot. I used a medium and was glad I sampled before chilling. The onion was over-powering and would have completely taken over the flavors. I ended up digging out a lot of onion - about half and it was very good but still had an onion aftertaste the next day. A large mild onion like Vidalia or Walla Walla would be good. Scallions may be nice with this recipe. I skipped the carrot but included the pimento. A really good dish.

text:
This was an excellent salad - personally I didn't notice the extra sweetness others are commenting on.  Overall, it sort of had a deviled egg appeal with the added mustard which I really liked.  Like most of you, I added my own personal twist.  I wanted that extra toothiness so cut two chicken breasts into strips, cooked them and  let them cool to room temp.  Once completely cool I shredded them into the finished salad and incorporated fully. Additionally,  I also substituted the green pepper with a red pepper to give that visual pop since I left out the pimentos.  Enjoy!

text:
Well, I wish I had read ALL of the reviews before making this.  I have never made a macaroni salad before so I didn't think twice about adding the sugar.  For us it was just too sweet. Chilling the salad does take some of the sweetness away but not enough. Not the taste we were looking for.  It was more like eating a "honey mustard" macaroni salad rather than a "classic".  When I was mixing the dressing I couldn't help thinking the sauce would have been better on chicken than using it in a salad.  Would maybe make this again but definately NO sugar.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i found this recipe really helpful! this was the first time i ever attempted to make macaroni salad, and it was a hit. i did improvise a bit though. 

- instead of using 1/4 cup vinegar, i only used 1/8.
- instead of using 2/3 cup sugar, i only used 1/8.
- i used guldens spicy hot mustard instead of the prepared yellow mustard.
- instead of adding celery, bell pepper and carrot, i added cucumber and chunks of ham.
- i didnt have any pimento peppers, so i took that out too. 

overall, i love the way my macaroni salad came out. the only downfall was, it was a bit watery. this recipe definitely isnt what youre looking for if you want a thick and creamy macaroni salad. 

i will definitely be making this again. 

by the way, i used rotini instead of elbow macaroni, and it worked just fine! :)

This was the first time I had ever made a macaroni salad. I had to make it for a company picnic and I have to say that everyone just loved it. All my co-workers wanted to recipe...and one of them even thought about it they had it for a late breakfast snack and for lunch!

This is a great recipe that overall had people saying that it was the best macaroni salad they ever had.

text:
Being that I’m from the south I am used to macaroni salad being on the sweeter side. However, this was way too sweet for me. It’s a great salad. But if you do not like super sweet than I would suggest adding in only 1/4 Cup sugar and adding by taste if that’s not enough!  My first 1/2 batch was horribly sugary, so I made a second 1/2 batch with no sugar at all and mixed both batches together to balance out. I needed leftovers anyways. I also got a little carried away with grating the carrots so I just added the extras in.

text:
2/3 cup of sugar sounded way sweet. So I followed advice of others and cut it in half. Cut the amount of onion by half. Omitted the carrots. Didn't have fresh pimentos but the jarred type was fine substitute and added plenty sweetness to make up for reduced sugar.  It tastes similar to, but better than,  the store bought stuff at a fraction of price. I like how it stays a little wet over time like store-bought.  Possibly because this recipe doesn't use milk. I guess the macaroni doesn't absorb vinegar?  After this,   I WILL NEVER USE SWEET PICKLE RELISH AGAIN like other recipes call for. No complaints from others either.  A keeper and will definitely make again.  Thanks.

I have made this macaroni salad many, many times, and it is always a hit. The dressing is phenomenal, but I do cut  the sugar in half. I  find it just the right amount of sweetness to my taste. Since I love stuff in the salad, I also add more celery, carrots and peppers to the dish. I leave out the pimentos, and use black olives , and also cut up a whole block of cheddar cheese. The recipe is so versatile, you can doctor it in many ways!!!

Display Name:
Judy Lewis

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6312520.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this salad for a funeral luncheon.   I used an entire 16-ounce box of macaroni.  I only used 1/2 teaspoon of mustard since I am not a fan of the mustard taste.   I did not use the onion, green bell pepper nor the pimento peppers as I avoid these foods regularly.  I used more celery and carrots in my recipe.  I mixed up the ingredients the night before I needed the dish.   I think the taste was excellent!  The dressing was definitely not runny but my salad seemed a touch "dry" the next day.  So the only other change that I would make next time is to mix half of the dressing the night prior to serving the salad.  Mix in the remaining half of the dressing an hour prior to serving the dish.  I will definitely be making this macaroni salad again and again.  I do think I might also try this dressing for a cole slaw dish too.

Gloria

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/401597.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading lots of the reviews, I was prepared for a sweeter macaroni salad.  I think if the name were "Sweet and Tangy Macaroni Salad," most would be more prepared for the flavor.  My husband and I thought it was good and would probably make the perfect pot luck dish because it has such a unique flavor that doubtfully anyone else would duplicate the dish.  I cut the recipe down to 5 servings (based on the automatic serving calculator) and only used 1/4 cup sugar (vs 1/3 that is listed for 5 servings). I set the macaroni and sauce in the fridge (separately) for 48 hrs.  The sauce is perfect smoothness for the macaroni.  The taste was really good (sweet and tangy) and I think would go well with pork chops, fried chicken, etc..  Next time, I think I would cut back just a bit more on the sugar and maybe even the vinegar but not by much or it would taste like all the other recipes.  Definitely something worth making again now that I know what flavor to really expect. Thanks for the recipe Graden.
